column1: Gender
column2: age

column1: In general
column2: persons of 15 years or older took part in this study
column3: the well-being figures only apply to the Dutch population of 18 years or older. Therefore
column4: this table consists of well-being figures of the Dutch population of 18 years or older in terms of happiness
column16: social life and the amount of free time. In addition
column18: feelings of unsafety and trust in others are included. Satisfaction with work and the travel time to and from work are measured only for people who have a paid job for 12 hours per week or more. For people who do not work or work less than 12 hours per week satisfaction with daily activities is reported. These subjects are reported for gender

1. GENERAL INFORMATION
In general
column2: persons of 15 years or older took part in this study
column3: the well-being figures only apply to the Dutch population of 18 years or older. Therefore
column4: this table consists of well-being figures of the Dutch population of 18 years or older in terms of happiness
column16: social life and the amount of free time. In addition
column18: feelings of unsafety and trust in others are included. Satisfaction with work and the travel time to and from work are measured only for people who have a paid job for 12 hours per week or more. For people who do not work or work less than 12 hours per week satisfaction with daily activities is reported. These subjects are reported for gender

column1: Data available from: 2013
Status of the figures:
The figures in this table are definite.
Changes as of March 20th
Not applicable
column2: this is a new table.

column1: When will new figures be published?
New figures on 2020 will be published around the middle of 2021.
2. DEFINITIONS AND EXPLANATION OF SYMBOLS
Explanation of symbols:
Empty cell	: figure not applicable
. 		: figure is unknown
column2: insufficiently reliable or confidential

column1: *		: provisional figure
**		: revised provisional figure
3. LINKS TO RELEVANT TABLES AND ARTICLES
Relevant tables:
Well-being in relation to health and life style; health characteristics (Dutch only)
Well-being in relation to education and work; work characteristics (Dutch only)
Well-being in relation to finance; finance characteristics (Dutch only)
Well-being in relation to living; living characteristics (Dutch only)
Well-being in relation to social life; social life characteristics (Dutch only)
(Un)safety perception; background characteristics (Safety monitor)(Dutch only)
Relevant articles:
More satisfied with life with stronger neighborhood cohesion (Dutch only).
Dutch more satisfied with own finances (Dutch only).

The survey method for this table can be found in the survey description Sociale cohesion and well-being (Dutch only).

2012655;"Background: western";"Person with a western migration background
Person originating from a country in Europe (excluding Turkey)
column2: North America or Oceania

column1: Due to their socioeconomic and cultural position people from Indonesia and Japan residing in the Netherlands are considered as having a western migration background. 2018710;"Level of educ: (pre-) Primary educ.";"The educational level is (pre-)primary education.

column1: 2018720;"Level of educ: Lower secondary educ..";"The educational level is lower secondary education.

column1: 2018750;"Level of educ: Upper secondary";"The educational level is upper secondary education.

column2: vwo)
column4: the vocational professional track (mbo3) and the vocational middle-management and specialist track (mbo4)."

B000167;"Average/percentage";""

B000150;"Standard error";"The figures are based on samples and will therefore not be strictly equal to the true value as it occurs in a population. The standard error gives an idea of the accuracy of the estimate made. When multiplied by 1.96
column2: the standard error gives the 95% confidence interval. The confidence interval indicates between which values the true value will probably fall. The standard error depends on the sample size
column3: among other things. The smaller the standard error
column4: the more accurate the estimate is."
